fulltext:
к.  M.  T.  Chrimes : Ancient Sparta
619
Patronomoi in chronological order,  on which the dating of this material is based.  But this list,  as will be seen below,  is in several details far from satisfactory ; and consequently some of the conclusions based on the dates of the Patronomoi Ьесопге untenable.  Besides this,  the list of Kasens ( pp.  452—6 ) does not seem to confirm in every instance that the »patrons « came from the older and more distinguished families,  when we find them with such names as Nedymos and Phileros,  which would rather suggest a parvenu origin.  The fact,  also,  that some of the boy victors who are styled Kasen bear names of »aristocratic« type is a further warning against bold generalisations in this field.  The occurence of a Kasen named Damion,  whose father M.  Antistius Philokrates was a Roman citizen ( JG,  V.  i,  281 ),  must be due to some exceptional,  but perhaps not unique,  circumstances,  as the author realises ( p.  456,  note 3 ).  On the whole,  however,  she has given us a more satisf^ying interpretation of the word Kasen than any previous suggestion,  at any rate as regards admission to the Agelai ; but the curious feature that a change of name was apparently insisted on before a Kasen could proceed to hold office,  if in fact this was the case,  still lacks a satisfactory explanation. 
Turning to the details of the nacôiKoç àycov^ the sickle dedicated by the victor is interpreted as a military weapon carried by the Epheboi in their training and identified with the ivijXr ] ( cf.  Xen. ,  Anab.  iv.  7,  16 ),  and fore has nothing to do with agricultural uses or with the ( purely cal ) aspect of Orthia as a vegetation - goddess ( as proposed by H.  J.  Rose,  Art.  Orth,  p.  406 ).  This seems to confirm almost beyond doubt the author's view that the dedicators were Epheboi ; but the additional suggestion,  put forward in chapter X ( J'he Cult of Orthid ) that it derives from the Cretan weapon carried by the »young warrior« on the Hagia Triadha cup and by the armed goddess on a seal from Knossos ( illustrated on PI.  IV ),  with which »a close correspondence in form « is claimed ( p.  25 5 ),  is not confirmed by the illustration and is in itself highly improbable. 
A further statement ( p.  99 ),  which must not go unchallenged,  is that the dedication of a sickle was,  in general,  only permitted to a Kasen in the period before Hadrian,  and that »from this time onwards ( and,  as we may suspect,  from the date of one of Hadrian's visits to Sparta in A.  D.  125 and 128 ) a Boagos,  although he had not actually competed,  had apparently the exclusive right to claim victory on behalf of any victor in his year - class ( fiixixiôôofAEvoi velsim.  ) and to dedicate the sickle «.  This is most misleading,  for we have ( in IG.  V.  i,  275 ) a definite dedication by a Boagos in the year of P.  Memmius Theokles,  whom Miss Chrimes herself dates to c.  89 / 90 ; this is probably the earliest example,  for her proposed date for the victory of — Archiadas ( JG.  V.  i,  531 ) »c.  60—5 «,  on a fragment which lacks the name of the Patronomos,  is in my opinion at least seventy - five years too early,  as it combines the formula ^Ayaêrj riJXT ) with the archaising nomina -
